Steve Freeman wrote:

> My one caveat is that this makes mocking a testing technique, so it's 
> good for working with external libraries. How do you get the (asserted) 
> benefits of mocks as a design technique for new code?

I'm not completely sure what you mean.  I think that you mean writing 
your mocks along with your tests, and building/refactoring them as you 
progressively flesh out your design (as has been discussed recently on 
the test driven development mailing list).

In any case, I think that you are pointing out what I perceive to be the 
major drawback of any dynamic mock approach (virtual mocks or dynamic 
proxies).  This drawback is reusability.  If you mock everything on a 
per-call basis, then this is obviously specific to the current test 
scenario.  You can't reuse this "mock" in another test which may reqire 
the mocking of completely different calls to the object.

With a "real" mock/fake object (one that is actually a compiled class), 
  you can define default behaviors (return values / parameter 
validations) which will always be used no matter what context you use 
the object in.

It looks like DynaMock is working towards an innovative solution to this 
problem, in the form of "default return stubs" 
(http://www.mockobjects.com/wiki/ChangesInNatsBranch).

With this approach, I can see that dynamic/virtual mocks can possibly 
achieve the same reusability benefits as "real" mocks.  This could be 
done by "pre-configuring" dynamic/virtual mock objects which are 
reusable across tests.  In other words, defining what should happen for 
each possible method call on the object, regardless of the current context.

If this were made easy to do, then I can see dynamic/virtual mocks being 
  indistinguishable from "real" mocks in terms of functionality.  You 
can still use an interface-driven design process, except it would be 
without the interfaces.

I'm still trying to get the concept of interface driven design, so I may 
be off base.  Let me know what you think.

-- Chad
